STATE OF MICHIGAN
GRETCHEN WHITMER DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES ELIZABETH HERTEL
GOVERNOR LANSING DIRECTOR
July 12, 2022
Carol Kehoe
Ingham County DHHS
P. O. Box 30088
Lansing, MI 48909
RE: License #: CP330201190
Investigation #: 2022C0212014
Ingham County DHHS
Dear Ms. Kehoe:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the local office at (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
SPECIAL INVESTIGATION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP330201190
Investigation #: 2022C0212014
Complaint Receipt Date: 05/05/2022
Investigation Initiation Date: 05/06/2022
Report Due Date: 07/04/2022
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator: Carol Kehoe, Administrator
Licensee Designee: Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: Ingham County DHHS
Facility Address: 5303 S Cedar Street
Lansing, MI 48909
Facility Telephone #: (517) 887-9791
Original Issuance Date: 10/01/1991
License Status: REGULAR
Effective Date: 12/01/2020
Expiration Date: 11/30/2022
Capacity: Unknown
Program Type: CHILD PLACING AGENCY, FIA
1

II. ALLEGATION
Violation
Established?
Foster Care Agency did not follow-up and ensure medical and Yes
dental needs for a vulnerable youth were met for the three years
youth remained in placement. Foster youth has special health
care needs and lost weight while in his previous placement for 3
years.
III. METHODOLOGY
05/05/2022 Special Investigation Intake 2022C0212014
05/06/2022 Special Investigation Initiated – Telephone
05/09/2022 Contact - Document Sent. Email with agency CA and PM
05/11/2022 Contact - Face to Face. Interviews completed on-site
05/24/2022 Contact - Document Sent. Email to Licensing Supervisor
05/25/2022 Contact - Document Received. Email from Licensing Supervisor
06/07/2022 Contact - Document Sent. Email to Licensing Worker
06/28/2022 Contact - Telephone call made. Phone call with Foster Parent
06/29/2022 Contact - Document Received. Email from Licensing Worker
07/12/2022 Contact - Telephone call. Pre-exit with administrator.
ALLEGATION:
Foster Care Agency did not follow-up and ensure medical and dental needs for a
vulnerable youth were met for the three years youth remained in placement. Foster
youth has special health care needs and lost weight while in his previous placement
for 3 years.
INVESTIGATION:
On 5/5/2022 DCWL received the allegation regarding Youth A and his placement
with Foster Parent 1. Youth A’s case record in MiSACWIS was reviewed and found
the following relevant information:
 Youth A, now age 18, entered care in February 2019.
 Youth A was hospitalized when entering care due to severe neglect, parental
substance abuse, inadequate housing, and malnourishment due to frequent
starvation and dehydration. Youth A was premature- born at 24 weeks
gestation, with Down Syndrome.
 Youth A was determined to be Medically Fragile.
 Youth A was placed with Foster Parent 1 from 3/8/2019 to 1/21/2022.
 3/15/2019 Well child exam documented Youth A had Down Syndrome and
nutritional deficiency. Youth A was prescribed tums for calcium, Vitamin D
drops and PediaSure nutritional supplement three times per day.
 3/19/2019 Well child exam noted Youth A was 49lbs. when he entered care.
Youth A’s weight at this visit was 58lbs. Foster Parent 1 was advised to feed
2

three meals per day, plus snacks, and PediaSure/Ensure supplement daily.
Advised not to give Youth A milk and to re-check bloodwork in three months.
Specialists follow up recommended: Ophthalmology, dental, hand, scoliosis,
and hearing screening. Growth and development will continue to be
monitored. No documentation of referrals provided for these services.
 5/14/2019 Dental exam attempted.
 5/17/2019 Dental exam completed- everything looked good, but they were
unable to take x-rays due to patient’s behavior.
 1/21/2020 Dental exam. Sedation required due to child refusing to cooperate
and flailing in chair. Referred Foster Parent 1 to sedation dentist in Grand
Rapids. Foster Parent 1 expressed she cannot brush Youth A’s teeth as he
flails and tries to hurt her.
 6/25/2020 Well child exam- 4’3” tall, 58lbs. No acute distress. Appeared
active/alert. “On small side.” No concerns noted, no referrals made.
 8/10/2020 Exam delayed due to COVID closing physician offices. Well child
exam reported Youth A was 4’3” tall, 58lbs. Prescribed nutritional supplement
four times per day, three meals per day. Youth A could not tolerate fruits,
juice, vegetables, or sauces. Difficulty brushing teeth. Physician noted Youth
A’s general appearance was small, but he was not under distress and
appeared active/alert. Youth A was described as anxious, non-verbal, with a
history of failure to thrive. Plan was to monitor weight closely. Reviewed diet
with foster parent. Youth A identified as being short stature for age with
delayed puberty. Discussed referral to endocrinologist.
 8/16/2021 New patient well child exam reported “well-appearing adolescent
for WCC. Growing and developing well”. Documented significant delays,
Down Syndrome, non-verbal. Youth A appeared underweight and physician
recommended a diet including five servings of fruit/vegetables per day and no
sweetened beverages or sweets, appropriate dairy intake, and calcium intake
and three meals per day, well balanced diet, normal portions. Youth A
documented as 4’3” and 55lbs. Physical exam: “well developed, well-
nourished and no acute distress”.
 1/21/22 New patient visit with new foster parent. Youth A was 4’3”, 51lbs.
Exam identified history of short stature for age. Concerns about Youth A
choking when swallowing, abnormal gait, Down Syndrome, and need for
dental visit.
 4/14/22 Dental- sedation dental completed. A few cavities noted.
 Special Evaluation initiated with Foster Parent 1 on 4/25/22 due to concerns
about Youth A’s weight and medical care. Licensing Worker 1 was assigned
to investigate.
 5/9/22 Well child exam. Height of 4’3”, weight 70lbs. Youth A spits up at
times, swallow study was normal. Good energy, good appetite. Follow-up to
address possible scoliosis. Underweight, but gaining with current regimen.
3

Referral to pediatric endocrinologist and bone age study. Referral for pediatric
gastroenterologist.
Chief Administrator
On 5/9/22 the Chief Administrator (CA) was notified of the allegations. CA
assisted with scheduling interviews with workers that are involved in the case
and with the foster home.
Licensing Worker 1
Licensing Worker 1 was interviewed on-site on 5/11/22. Licensing Worker 1
reported being assigned to investigate the allegations regarding Foster Parent 1.
Licensing Worker 1 reported reviewing Youth A’s case in MiSACWIS and
determined his weight changed from 59lbs in March 2019 to 51lbs in January 2022.
Youth A’s new provider, Foster Parent 2, reported he gained twenty pounds since
moving to her home. Licensing Worker 1 reported they would speak with the Health
Liaison Officer (HLO) for the county to see if there were any appointments that
were not completed by Foster Parent 1. Licensing Worker 1 noted the well child
exams on file did not document medical interventions or referrals. Licensing
Worker 1 reported Foster Parent 1 was feeding Youth A a pureed diet as
prescribed, due to Youth A choking on pieces of food or throwing up. Foster Parent
1 also told the worker that Youth A was very active and would lose weight easily.
Licensing Worker 2
Licensing Worker 2 was interviewed on-site on 5/11/22. Licensing Worker 2 is the
regularly assigned worker for Foster Parent 1. Licensing Worker 2 stated she felt
Foster Parent 1 did well with Youth A and did not have any concerns. During home
visits Youth A was always playing with toys and active. No concerns in the home
were identified. Licensing Worker 2 was aware of Youth A’s small stature and
weight and did not observe anything that indicated he was not being taken care of.
Foster Parent 1 informed Licensing Worker 2 about difficulties with Youth A's
school following his diet. The school was not pureeing Youth A’s food, which
caused him to choke or throw up. Foster Parent 1 then began sending all of his
food daily, to ensure the school followed the plan. In Licensing Worker 2’s opinion,
Foster Parent 1 seemed to be a strong advocate for Youth A and did not express
any difficulty in scheduling appointments or getting referrals.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
FCW was interviewed on-site on 5/11/22. FCW reported being assigned as Youth
A’s case manager for the past year and taking him to the well child exam in August
2021, at which time no concerns were found by the physician. FCW reported that
Youth A has gained 21lbs since changing placements in January 2022. FCW
reported that Youth A recently had a swallow study completed and it was
determined that he was not chewing his foods. This is likely due to Youth A having
low cognitive ability and an infant swallowing mechanism. Youth A was placed on
a strict puree diet with a supplemental drink (Ensure).
4

FCW reported she did not have any prior concerns with Youth A’s placement in
Foster Parent 1’s home. FCW felt the foster parent did the best she could with the
knowledge she had. When asked about specialist referrals for Youth A, FCW
stated she was unsure if there were any referrals given to Foster Parent 1, or if
discussions occurred at the doctor’s office. FCW never saw any referrals.
FCW acknowledged difficulty with Youth A’s dental care, as he would not
cooperate for any brushing or exams. Dental exams required sedation, which was
difficult to find in their area and required travel over an hour away. In addition, the
sedation dentistry was not covered by Youth A’s medical plan, which resulted in
Foster Parent 1 paying out of pocket. FCW was not aware of any assistance
provided to Foster Parent 1 regarding daily dental care or six-month dental exams.
FCW was unsure if the worker or HLO was responsible for following up on missing
medical/dental information. FCW stated MISACWIS does not currently flag or alert
staff to things such as weight loss, missing medical documentation, or
unscheduled referrals. FCW stated she was unsure if Foster Parent 1 was given a
referral by a physician, but then did not notify the agency or follow-up with the
referral, noting agency staff would have no way of knowing unless the foster parent
told them. FCW stated she hoped the findings of this investigation would help make
some recommendations on how to handle cases with medical needs. FCW verified
Youth A was Medically Fragile Level 4, meaning that he was cognitively delayed,
non-verbal, and unable to do any of his personal care. FCW noted Youth A seems
very happy in his new placement. While FCW felt Foster Parent 1 did well with
meeting his needs, the new placement seems to be more active in advocating for
his care.
Licensing Supervisor
Licensing Supervisor was met on-site on 5/11/22 with a follow-up phone call later
that day. Licensing Supervisor reported that Foster Parent 1 asked for Youth A to
move in January 2022, as she was exhausted from caring for him, and the other
special needs children in the home. Youth A was moved to the home of Foster
Parent 2, where he continues a puree diet and supplement drinks.
Licensing Supervisor did not have any concerns about the care Youth A received
at Foster Parent 1’s home. Licensing Supervisor was aware of the feeding
difficulties Foster parent 1 experienced with Youth A, but believed she had a good
plan in place to maintain his weight. In addition, there was no concern expressed
by physicians that had treated Youth A over the past three years. Since Youth A
was already 18 years old, no one was expecting for Youth A to grow or gain a
significant amount of weight at this point. It appeared his malnourishment prior to
entering care, along with his developmental delays, was the cause for his small
stature. There was no concern that Foster Parent 1 was the cause of Youth A’s
small size or low weight.
5

Licensing Supervisor reported that Foster Parent 2 is a good advocate for special
needs children and focused on advocating for Youth A to determine if any other
medical services are needed.
Foster Parent 1
On 6/28/2022 a phone interview was completed with Foster Parent 1.
Foster Parent 1 reported Youth A was underweight and very small when he was
first placed in her home. Youth A had Down Syndrome and had been
malnourished for years before entering care. After moving to her home, Youth A
attended a school for special needs children. The school was concerned about
Youth A’s weight and tried to “fatten him up” by giving him unhealthy foods that
were mostly carbohydrates and junk food. This caused Youth A to be bloated,
feel unwell, and have diarrhea. It was unknown at the time if Youth A had any
allergies or intolerances. Therefore, Foster Parent 1 was determined to figure out
what healthy items he could successfully eat. Youth A’s diet consisted of healthy
carbohydrates, proteins, and some fruits/vegetable. When the school continued
to feed Youth A junk and cause him digestive issues, Foster Parent 1 began
providing the school with food. Within the first few months of placement, Youth A
gained 10lbs.
Youth A then entered a phase where he was putting things in his mouth, ranging
from other people’s food to non-food items such as crayons. Youth A did not
have the ability to regulate feelings of hunger, or feelings of wanting to chew.
This also resulted in Youth A trying to swallow large items, vomit, then swallow
the item again. Therefore, Foster Parent 1 began giving him very small bites of
food. When the regurgitation continued, she began pureeing Youth A’s food. This
seemed to deter Youth A from intentionally vomiting. Foster Parent 1 continued
providing the school with food for Youth A, in puree form. In addition, Youth A
drank Ensure 3-5 times per day, to increase his calorie intake.
Foster Parent 1 reported Youth A was not gaining much weight at her house, but
he was not losing weight either and his digestive system seemed to stabilize.
Foster Parent 1 felt this was a success as long as his weight maintained. Foster
Parent 1 reported Youth A’s doctor was pleased with her strategy and did not
have concerns about his low weight, considering his history. Foster Parent 1
stated agency staff never reported concern about Youth A’s weight.
Foster Parent 1 stated that Youth A was constantly on the move, which made it
even more difficult for him to gain weight. Foster Parent 1 denied receiving any
referrals for a swallowing test or other specialists. Foster Parent 1 noted that an
agency worker took Youth A to a medical appointment in August 2021. This
appointment was with a new doctor. When Foster Parent 1 reviewed the health
exam form, she found it to be incorrect as it stated Youth A was “normal, average
size”. Foster Parent 1 stated that she wished the agency would have been more
vocal with the doctor in that exam.
6

Licensing Worker 1
On 6/29/22 Licensing Worker 1 reported that her investigation had concluded
and the agency found Foster Parent 1 in compliance with licensing rules.
Licensing Worker 1 further stated the agency is reviewing how to better support
the needs of children with specialized care.
APPLICABLE RULE
FOM 801-01 Health Requirements
Page 3-11
Page 3- A dental re-examination must be obtained at least every
six months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
Page 9- The caseworker is responsible for reviewing the
information within the child’s well child exam form, the DHS-
1664, Youth Health Record, Dental form, and other medical,
dental, and mental health reports and/or assessments. If follow-
up medical or dental care or mental health treatment is
recommended, the caseworker must ensure that the
recommendations are followed.
Page 11-Health services for children with chronic health care
needs, such as children identified as medically fragile and/or
within the Children’s Special Health Care Services (CSHCS)
program require ongoing follow-up by the caseworker.
ANALYSIS: Page 3- A violation was found as dental exams were not
completed every six months as required. Exams were missing
for July 2020, January 2021, and January 2022.
Page 9- A violation was found as well-child exams from 2019-
2021 documented a need for referrals and follow-up regarding
Child A’s health conditions and a need to closely monitor his
weight. However, no follow-up was documented.
Page 11- A violation was found as Youth A is a Medically
Fragile child, with several health conditions. Medical exams
noted a need for follow-up and referrals. There was no
documentation to indicate these specialist referrals were
provided to the foster parent by the physician. There was also
no documentation to indicate the worker followed-up with Child
A's physician regarding his health or medical needs.
CONCLUSION: REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
10/27/2021 INTERIM, CAP approved 11/24/2021
7

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Upon receipt of an acceptable CAP, I recommend no change in the license status.
_ _____________July 11, 2022_
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
July 11, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
8
